ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack Citations ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail In a formerly widespread approach to medical decision-making, physicians made a diagnosis, considered the management alternatives, and informed patients what would be done to help them. Decision-making rested exclusively in the physicians' domain.This parental model of patient care challenged clinicians to interpret what was best for their patients. How much benefit must a treatment offer before it was worth subjecting a patient to its short-term side effects, long-term risks, inconveniences, and costs? With the clinician at the center of decision-making, the question was whether a treatment effect was "clinically relevant."
